subject: International Quikscript
msgSnippet: ... There are enough clues in The Manual that we can figure one out, though. ... Fortunately, there are no universal splits that would have to be represented,
messageBody:
peter_r_guinness scripsit:

> The problem is that we don't have an agreed upon international version.

There are enough clues in The Manual that we can figure one out, though.

> This was discussed quite a bit a long time ago-- the main issues is
> what to do with mergers and splits of some accents,

Fortunately, there are no universal splits that would have to be
represented, and although there are only a few truly universal mergers
("vain" and "vein", for example, or "bred" and "bread"), the mergers
represented by "meet" and "meat", "toe" and "tow", and "through" and
"threw" are still incomplete only in a few accents of the U.K.

> particularly the differences between the UK accents and the American
> accents. (eg: the caught/cot merger in General American).

That's just something Americans (actually, only about 50% of them)
will have to learn, just as most anglophones will have to learn when to
write 18 Way and when to write 20 Why, because they no longer distinguish
them in speech. (The distinction is still robust in Scotland, Ireland,
and the American South.)

> I think most would agree that RP could be used as a standard for UK
> English, cause most Britians know what it sounds like and can imagine
> how to write it.

That's about the best we can do. QS is definitely problematic when
compared to Orthodox for many U.K. accents, because it merges away
distinctions that are vital to them, like the Scottish English distinction
between "fern", "fir", and "fur".

> I do support the idea that a true international quickscript should
> include the rhotic 'r' though it is a little difficult for us non-
> rhotic speakers to know where to put them but not overly so.

Of the 24 Wells lexical sets for stressed vowels, we can immediately
assign the 15 non-rhotic ones as follows:

KIT = 26 It
FLEECE = 27 Eat
DRESS = 28 Et
FACE = 29 Eight
TRAP = 30 At
PRICE = 31 I
PALM = 32 Ah
THOUGHT = 33 Awe
LOT = 34 Ox
CHOICE = 35 Oy
STRUT = 36 Utter
MOUTH = 37 Out
GOAT = 38 Owe
FOOT = 39 Foot
GOOSE = 40 Ooze

Thus, for example, Americans outside Eastern New England will need to
learn to distinguish LOT words from PALM words, writing the former with
34 Ox and the latter with 32 Ah. By the same token, New Zealanders
will need to learn to distinguish KIT words from STRUT words, writing
the former with 26 It and the latter with 36 Utter.

Of the 7 rhotics, The Manual tells us these either explicitly or by
example:

NURSE = 36 Utter + 25 Roe
START = 32 Ah + 25 Roe
SQUARE = 29 Eight + 25 Roe
NEAR = 27 Eat + 25 Roe
FORCE = 33 Awe + 25 Roe

It's not clear what to do with the CURE and NORTH lexical sets. In RP
all three sound the same, although the change of CURE was probably not
yet standard in Reid's day. For the sake of American understanding,
probably the best choice is:

CURE = 40 Ooze + 25 Roe

Most accents have merged the NORTH set (which is pretty small) into
FORCE, so that "horse" (NORTH) and "hoarse" (FORCE) sound the same.
Making everyone learn this distinction for the sake of those in Scotland,
Ireland, Eastern New England, and the Caribbean who have it seems like
overkill, but we could allow an alternative here:

NORTH = 33 Awe + 25 Roe (most speakers)
NORTH = 38 Owe + 25 Roe (those speakers who distinguish)

The two remaining stressed-vowel lexical sets, BATH and CLOTH, are never
pronounced distinctly from any other set, so they don't need their own
letters. Most Americans outside Eastern New England, and most non-RP
speakers in the U.K., pronounce the BATH words like the TRAP set; most
others like the PALM set. Since the set of BATH words is smaller in
Australia than in RP, I propose adhering to Orthodox here and writing:

BATH = 30 At

Similarly, most North Americans pronounce the CLOTH set like the THOUGHT
set, most other anglophones pronounce it like the LOT set. So again
I'd use Orthodox as the tie-breaker and write:

CLOTH = 34 Ox

Lastly, the four unstressed sets have spellings prescribed in The Manual:

happY = 26 It
commA = 36 Utter
lettER = 36 Utter + 25 Roe
intO = 40 Ooze

It's possible that the use of 26 It rather than 27 Eat for happY should
be reconsidered, as almost all speakers have shifted to it.
